headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: J.D. Vance and Tim Ryan Battle For Ohio Senate Seat; In Michigan's Governor's race, Gov. Whitmer Faces GOP's Dixon; $1.9 Billion Powerball Drawing Delayed Due To "Security Protocols." Aired 5:30-6a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So, inflation is soaring and the U.S. is staring down a possible recession. Today's midterm elections may come down to a familiar truism of American politics coined by James Carville -- "It's the economy, stupid."(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: They're strangling Ohio families with soaring prices and crippling inflation.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Since I came to office we've created 10 million new jobs, 3.75 percent unemployment.MEHMET OZ, (R) PENNSYLVANIA SENATE CANDIDATE:  And you've got, amazingly, seniors who are saying their Social Security checks -- they just don't stretch far enough anymore with runaway inflation. LT. GOV. JOHN FETTERMAN, (D) PENNSYLVANIA SENATE CANDIDATE:  I think it's also really critical that our next senator really understands inflation. Inflation is a tax on working people. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Joining us now is CNN's chief business correspondent Christine Romans. Good morning.CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT, ANCHOR, "EARL START":  Hi.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So we hear all the rhetoric around --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- what's happening with the economy, inflation, a looming recession, and so forth. That's the rhetoric around it. Give us the facts -- just the facts.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: You know, I think it's a mixed picture in the U.S. economy but you have some headline numbers that are really dangerous for the party in power, and that is inflation running at a 40-year high. I mean, you just haven't had a midterm election with inflation like this since the Carter administration or the early days of the -- of the Reagan administration. So it's just a situation we haven't seen --

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: -- in our lifetimes, really -- or remember in our lifetimes, at least.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: One of the points that the Biden administration consistently makes on this is hey, the U.S. -- we're sort of in the middle of the pack --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- in terms of OECD countries, right --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- developed economies. But when you look at the numbers, right now, you still have a lot of big economies with lower inflation than the U.S. Brazil, China, Canada, India, Japan, France -- they are lower --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, because you can't tell people hey, it's actually way better than you're feeling like it is. And that's been a struggle when you talk to White House officials --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- that I speak to almost every day. They say that is their greatest issue going into the midterm elections.But one thing President Biden also says is I'm relying on the Federal Reserve to deal --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- with the inflation issue. It's up to them however they best see fit.But talk to us about the cost of the Fed's war on inflation because that is what voters are feeling when they're making their decisions today.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: And so, the problem is the medicine to cure the patient, which is inflation -- the medicine tastes terrible and hurts, too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: You've got a stock market -- this is the second-worst year in -- for president -- in the stock market since Jimmy Carter, right? Probably the worst year for stocks since 2008. So you're 401(k) -- your retirement is down a little bit this year.You've also got home prices now that are going to be capped -- but guess what -- by these huge mortgage rates. So it's harder to buy a home. And then the grocery bill is still high. So, credit card rates -- can I just mention that credit card rates -- the average credit card rate is now 19 percent APR.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oof.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Keeping money -- if you can't pay off your credit card bill you are getting killed out there right now. And store credit cards, 29 percent.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oof.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: My advice for the holiday season is don't put it on a store credit card if you can't pay it off right away because --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's a blinking red light right there --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- because you get in that wheel --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And that's what everyone does, right, with the holidays.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. That's what higher rates mean. And so, people are kind of caught in that, too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: But I will say that household balance sheets are much better today than they were in 2008.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because they saved up a lot in the COVID and stimulus.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Because they saved up during COVID -- yes. And people were home for a year and a half.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So now they're spending money like crazy on, what, travel,

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Flying, eating.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: -- going out, entertainment.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: There's a disconnect. Tell me. I don't know --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: It is -- right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- what's up with that. But I wonder if there's any sugar when you said that it's the medicine that -- I wonder if there's some sugar that'll make this medicine go down.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Don's looking for some sweet -- sugar --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- good news this morning.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I need some Def Leppard going out of here.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They play -- they play us into commercial when we're late.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They're like stop talking.Thank you, Christine Romans.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Shut up.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We appreciate it.Up next --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Those are the closing arguments from the Senate candidates in Ohio. Polls are going to open there in about 45 minutes. J.D. Vance and Tim Ryan making their final pitch to voters as former President Trump was in the state.It's the seat left open by Republican Sen. Rob Portman, one of the most closely-watched races in the country. Trump, obviously, has been campaigning for J.D. Vance while Ryan has been running this aggressive campaign in a state where the GOP has dominated in recent years. So joining us now to talk about what we should expect today is Statehouse News bureau chief for Ohio Public Radio and Television, Karen Kasler. Karen, thanks so much for being here. And I know you've been watching all of this so closely. What have you heard from voters in the closing days as these polls are set to open in about 45 minutes from now? KAREN KASLER, STATEHOUSE NEWS BUREAU CHIEF, OHIO PUBLIC RADIO AND TELEVISION (via Webex by Cisco):  Well, the issue continues to be the economy. I think it's been that way through this whole campaign though, of course, there was a blip this summer where Democrats really gained some ground with the Dobbs decision overturning the right to abortion. But that economy issue and gas prices -- that's what you keep hearing from voters. And I think it shows in the way that Tim Ryan has been campaigning. He's really been chasing those moderate voters, those frustrated Trump voters, trying to lure them over rather than really focusing on the Democratic voters that are his base.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's a big, big topic. The same thing is happening in my home state of Alabama.Karen, I know you're going to be busy today, so thanks for taking some time to join us.

utterances.speaker: KASLER
utterances.sentences: It's great to talk to you -- thanks.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, let's go to Michigan where voters will decide the much-watched governor's race between Democratic incumbent Gretchen Whitmer and Republican challenger Tudor Dixon. Voters will also pick their next secretary of state, fill a number of house seats, and vote on a ballot measure that could guarantee the right to abortion.Joining us now, government and politics reporter for the Detroit Free Press, Dave Boucher. It's good to have you. What are you hearing and seeing on the ground from voters that you don't think is getting enough attention in the national -- on the national stage about these races? DAVE BOUCHER, GOVERNMENT AND POLITICS REPORTER, DETROIT FREE PRESS (via Skype):  Well, we've definitely also heard about inflation and gas prices, but there's a difference between what voters are concerned about and what's actually driving them to vote for a particular candidate. In our most recent poll, voters said inflation and the economy were the number one issue, but the number one issue driving their vote on the governor's race was abortion. So, as you noted, there's also a proposed constitutional amendment that would guarantee the right to an abortion in the state constitution in Michigan, and Gov. Gretchen Whitmer has really tied her fate to that. Polling has showed that both that constitutional amendment is probably going to pass and that Gov. Whitmer is sitting in a relatively strong position heading into Election Day. HARLOW:  But what I -- what I brought up earlier that I think is really interesting, Dave, though, is the fact that there are some voters that our folks are talking to -- Dana Bash was just there talking to a voter who said well, I voted for the ballot initiative to protect an abortion right, but because that was on there I felt free to vote for Tudor Dixon who does not support that -- which I found fascinating. And that's probably true of more than just one voter, no?

utterances.speaker: BOUCHER
utterances.sentences: Sure, it could be. We've seen in our crosstabs that there's a little bit of that going on. It's happening more in other races where voters don't know quite as much about the Republican candidate for attorney general, for example, who might have a significant role in enforcing any ban if the constitutional proposal fails.But overall, we're seeing a pretty strong correlation between Democratic candidates and people who support this constitutional amendment.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, good to have you. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Dave.New this morning, last night's Powerball drawing -- did you get it -- your ticket?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I didn't buy a ticket.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No, no, but we have time I guess.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It was delayed.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So you guys know what this is, right?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's not an omen for Election Day.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (Singing) Nothing I can say, total eclipse of the heart.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I may have gotten 12 text messages from my mother about well, honey, since you have to be up, make sure you don't miss the eclipse.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But what's funny is that we're on set so we can't see it, so we're watching that on the camera, of course -- there you see.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Sorry, mom.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is there an outdoors out there? We haven't left this studio and we won't for a while. COLLINSnight -- you know, this lottery issue. This is something that my dad --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- is not going to be pleased with.A technical problem delayed that gigantic $1.9 billion Powerball drawing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hmm.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The California Lottery announced late Monday night it had to delay the drawing because officials need more time to complete the security protocols.CNN's Martin Savidge is live in Atlanta. I don't know if you've bought any Powerball tickets, Martin, but what is happening with this, and what exactly are the security protocols that broke down here?

utterances.speaker: MARTIN SAVIDGE, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, first of all, I did see that moon and it did portend badly. We know what it's all about with the Powerball.You know, I have heard of flights being delayed, I've heard of trains being delayed. I've even heard of court cases being delayed. But this is a new one on me. I've never heard of the Powerball being delayed. And as you point out, Kaitlan, it's security protocols, which is a very mysterious realm because lottery officials are fanatical when it comes to their security protocols. Here's what we know. The lottery -- the Powerball is sold in at least 45 different states, plus the District of Columbia, plus Puerto Rico, plus the U.S. Virgin Islands. And in all of those independent lottery associations, they have to follow very strict security protocols. And they've got to tabulate and they've got to turn in their returns, and essentially, everything has to go perfectly. Somewhere along the lines last night it has not gone so. Now, quite frankly, with close to $2 billion on the line, it's not exactly a good look and we're still waiting to find out when this drawing is going to take place. Lottery officials do expect that it will take place today -- they just can say exactly what time it is going to take place. And we should point out the good news is if you bought a ticket, you haven't lost. The bad news is you just don't know if you're going to win. And by the way, if you're hoping that you can still rush out and go buy a ticket, I believe that train has already left the station.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That was --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That was our question.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. That was our --

utterances.speaker: SAVIDGE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- clarification we needed. So you can't go buy a ticket now and --

utterances.speaker: SAVIDGE
utterances.sentences: I would not try to do that. Things are already on edge in the Lottery Bureau these days. They don't need a last-minute rush of people coming in.The Mega Millions -- you can buy a ticket for that tonight. Who knows? They might hold the drawings back-to-back.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Marty.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Martin Savidge, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right. Next, we'll go live to several states where polls are just minutes away from opening.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait a minute -- where's the election music? Dom, dom, dom- dom-dom. Similar but not the same.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We've got hours for it (PH).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is the morning music.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, listen, we are a little bit punch-drunk (PH) because we've been already on the air for two hours.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But we have McDonald's coming because you ordered us breakfast.
